title: David Rach
text:
Baltimore



I am a 5th year PhD candidate in Molecular Microbiology and Immunology at the University of Maryland, Baltimore. My thesis project is focused on understanding how prenatal exposure to HIV affects the immune systems of HIV-exposed Uninfected (HEU) infants, and what the consequences of these exposures are in early life.









Volta Region, Ghana
After Wyoming, but before moving to Baltimore for graduate school, I served in the US Peace Corps as a Secondary Science Education Volunteer, in Ghana (West Africa) from 2016-2018, teaching biology and chemistry at a rural high school in the Volta region in the SE corner of the country.



 


Wyoming



I received my A.S in Natural Resources Biology from Northwest College, where thanks to the opportunities for undergraduate research supported by Wyoming INBRE I first became interested in Microbiology. I then transferred to the University of Wyoming where I completed my B.S. in Molecular Biology and Microbiology in 2016. It was here I became interested in Immunology, as I researched NK cell responses in mice to Toxoplasma gondii infection in the lab of Jason Gigley


 






Chiapas, Mexico
“Where are you from?” is a question I am frequently asked, but defies a simple answer. When I was two, my family moved to Chiapas, Mexico to work. And that’s where we remained.

title: David Rach
text: I am a Molecular Microbiology and Immunology PhD Candidate at the University of Maryland, School of Medicine in Baltimore, Maryland. My thesis advisers are Drs. Cristiana Cairo and Kirsten Lyke. My thesis is focused on understanding the impact that prenatal exposure to maternal HIV and/or antiretrovirals have on the innate-like and adaptive T cells in HIV-exposed Uninfected (HEU) infants, and what are the consequences of these exposures during early life.

title: Over-Caffenaited Rabbit Trails
text:
Should I be working on writing up my thesis right now? Yes.
Would it be easier to do it in Word? Probably
Am I using this as my excuse to learn how to use Quarto, so that I can use it for the Thesis writeup? Absolutely.

title: David Rach
text:
HEU Infants




It is estimated that 1.5 million HIV+ women give birth peryear. Thanks to improved antiretrovirals (and critically, access to them) vertical transmission from mother to child is increasingly prevented. These infants are exposed to effects of maternal virus (and viral proteins) in utero, but remain uninfected.
Despite not being infected, these infants have increased morbidity for respiratory and gastrointestinal infections during their first six months of life, compared to infants born to HIV- women living in the same communities.


To address contribution that these prenatal exposures have on the infant immune system, we are following a cohort of Malawian infants, born to


Innate-like T cells


Spectral Flow Cytometry
